ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We learned some more advanced Spanish grammar and read/watched some interesting stuff.
I learned more advanced grammar, vocabulary, watched Spanish language films, and discussed materials in Spanish to improve my speaking and listening ability.

The core of this course is a continuation of grammar from L3, but it takes you to a point where you can get by in just about any conversation with your grammatical skills and knowledge (though obviously not necessarily your vocabulary). The course also integrates short films and readings from South America that provide good practice and add a lot of depth to the curriculum.
Learned Spanish vocabulary and grammar

This course was amazing! The abroad experience is genuinely so special and unforgettable, and the course is taught super well. I think as long as you engage with it and try to use Spanish in your own time you will improve so much.
Spanish

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Honestly it is hard to tell which classes are which, but I wish we didn't have these silly projects and just had an oral exam I feel like I havent had time to learn a real L4 level of spanish because we only have like 10 real days of class that arent used for span 149 or the projects or the excursions.

We could cover more of the textbook, though I understand that there is less time during these four weeks due to the excursions. I do think fewer full classes could be spent on the films we watched to improve time management and the amount we learned. I liked the use of VHL and the textbook, and watching and listening to the final oral presentations.

Strengths: Explored a variety of different Spanish media (short films, movies, stories, newspaper articles, etc.)

Weakness: Course was heavily rushed so that it could fit into one month for Study Abroad.
The course is very immersive and this is great for learning, and the course content is also quite interesting.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Honestly no. I feel like the other programs like this one with YSS had so much more fun than us. Our schedules are PACKED we dont have time to really get to know or enjoy the city.
Not unless you really love grammar.

Yes, as long as they are willing to put in time outside of class. It is a great opportunity to learn Spanish and improve your ability to speak in new tenses and understand better what others are saying.

Yes. I would recommend the study abroad Quito program as a great way to learn a language in a different way and a different country. Quito is a great city and you'll leave wishing you had more time to explore.
Yes; I recommend that you complete Spanish during the summer rather than during the school year.
I would, if they want to learn Spanish and travel.
Sincerely doubt the Ecuador program will be ran again due to the hospitalizations and robbery that happened during the Summer 2023 session.
